etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in John Florio (1553–1625), author and teacher of languages. From retort + -able, originally after Middle French, French retorquable

definitions: That may be retorted; to which a retort may be made.

etymologies: late 19th century (in an earlier sense). From retort + -able

definitions: Especially of certain types of foil packaging and their contents: capable of undergoing thermal processing in a closed retort at temperatures above 100°C.
